fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44612].
  {panel}

Currently, on JIRA Workflow Post Function we could configured it to automatically assigned to a certain user using the Post Function when a transition is triggered. But, this could confuse users if the assignee field is shown on the transition screen and still selectable. As when the user is selecting any user, whomever the selected user is, it would change back to the user that is specified on the Post Function.

In this case, some improvement could be made like:
- Lock the assignee field, but still show the username that is specified on the Post Function.
- The assignee field is still shown and selectable, but when selecting other user it would override the Post Function.
fields.summary: Assigned Field to show the Username that is specified on the "Assigned to" post function.
The map on the confirmation email does not work
Cannot import from external system (e.g. CSV file) anymore

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44601].
  {panel}

After clicking "create" (submit) on the create issue dialog, a spinner comes up. Occasionally this spinner goes away and the issue is created but the dialog itself doesn't go away.

This introduces the opportunity for me to create duplicate issues. 

Additionally, there is no way to recover besides opening a new tab, and clicking on the "issues" drop down in order to check that my issue was indeed created. The reason that there is no way to recover is because the create dialog obscures the underlying content thus making the navigational elements of JIRA unavailable. 

For a novice computer user, for example one who doesn't understand tabs well, I would be faced with the decision to either:
a) Click create again and hope it works this time (thus creating a duplicate issue)
b) Hit cancel in the hopes that my issue had actually been created with the risk of losing the data that I had put into the create dialog.
fields.summary: Create issue dialog stops "spinning" with no obvious side effect

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44595].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
The use of the Agile Simplified Workflow enables project administrators to create issue statuses. Statuses from other boards are not visible when they are doing this from the Board Administration UI. This means many different issue statuses are created.

This makes it really difficult to manage the sort order or issue statuses.  Currently the statuses are presented in one big list with only "1 up" and "1 down" links to reorder them.  

h3. Suggested Solution

Add a multi-select field listing all the projects.  When an admin selects projects in the field the list of issue statuses is shortened to only those present in the issue status schemes of the projects.

Add a multi-select field listing all the JIRA Agile boards.  When an admin selects boards in the field the list of issue statuses is shortened to only those mapped to columns in those boards.
fields.summary: Ability to manage sequence of a subset of issue statuses for specific projects or boards

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44594].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
The use of the Agile Simplified Workflow enables project administrators to create issue statuses.  Statuses from other boards are not visible when they are doing this from the Board Administration UI.  This means many different issue statuses are created.

When searching this results in a very large list of issue status suggestions.  The searcher can't tell which ones are valid for a given set of projects or boards.

h3. Suggested Solution
A JQL function to suggest a constrained list of issue states.  This is just one idea, a different solution to the problem would be welcome.

Perhaps this would look like...
{code:borderStyle=solid}
status IN projectIssueStates((PROJECT_NAME [, PROJECT_NAME, ...]), (STATUS [, STATUS, ...]))
status IN boardIssueStates((BOARD_NAME [, BOARD_NAME, ...]), (STATUS [, STATUS, ...]))
{code}

By specifying a list of projects or boards to use as a constraint a sub-set of the global list of statuses can be suggested.  This saves the user from trying to determine the list of statuses used by the project or board.

Alternatively and perhaps more generally useful, use a sub-query to pull a list of issues then use the statuses from that list as suggestions.  Example:

{code:borderStyle=solid}
status IN filteredIssueStates("Project = TEST AND issueType != 'Epic'", (STATUS [, STATUS, ...]))
{code}

The suggested list would only include statuses present in the filtered list of issues.

NOTE: Consideration should be given to whether or not this would prevent referencing _other_ issue statuses.  In other words, if project TEST only has issues in Open, InProgress, and Done should the function allow an issue status list of (Open, InProgress, Done, PendingReview) or flag this as invalid?

h3. Workaround 

These are not great workarounds so please comment if you have other ideas.

* Ask and train project owners to prefix the statuses they create with their project key. Example: PROJA Waiting Approval.
* Ask/train project owners to maintain a list of statuses that are valid for their project to aid them in searching.  Others can refer to the project summary or Agile board to identify the statuses available.
fields.summary: Ability to constrain the list of suggested statuses in a JQL search to those that are valid for specific projects or boards

h3. Summary
When creating a custom field of type Select List (Single or Multi) and configuring it to be applicable to only a certain issue type, the Issue Navigator will not display any suggestions for Values

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field of type Select List (Single or Multi)
# Configure it to be applicable to only a certain issue type
!1.png|thumbnail!
# Navigate to the *Issue Navigator* and search for this custom field
!2.png|thumbnail!
# Include the particular Issue Type to the search in the Issue navigator as well
!3.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results
* There should be suggestions for the values of the custom field, at least for step 4 since we specified the issue type in the search

h3. Actual Results
* No suggestions for the values in both step 3 and step 4
 
h3. Notes
# Re-configure the custom field to be applicable to all Issue Types
!4.png|thumbnail!
# Search for this custom field in the Issue Navigator and the suggestions will show
!5.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround
No known workarounds
fields.summary: Issue Navigator doesn't suggest values for Select List custom field

fields.description:
In issue filtered view, when JQL is modified, the *Save as* button changes to *Save*. This is normal. If we also remove or add a column to result display, *Save* button is still there, and columns are saved with filter.

But if we don't change JQL filter, and we only add or remove a column for results display, the *Save as* button does not change to *Save*, so we cannot save the filter configuration. We have to save it as a new filter.

It seems the columns configuration change detection is not working, because it should trigger the switch from *Save as* to *Save*.
fields.summary: Save button does not appear in issue filter view when columns are modified.

fields.description:
JIRA issue update via rest on cold caches may take significant amount of time (15 min on a customer instance). Subsequent issue updates take reasonable amount of time (~30 seconds).

*Environment*
Many values in custom fields options:
{code:SQL}
select count(cfo.id),customfield.cfname from customfieldoption cfo join customfield on customfield.id=cfo.customfield group by customfield.cfname order by count(cfo.id) DESC limit 10;
{code}

*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a MulitSelect custom field
# Add many values to it (e.g. 1000 or 10'000).
# Add the MultiSelect custom field to the project screens (to be able to set it for an issue).
# Restart JIRA
# Query issue update via rest.
# Enable SQL logging

(!) *Result*
Issue update executes 1000 (or 10'000) requests to the database (see in SQL log). One per each value of a multi select.

(/) *Expected Result for Select*
We execute only single SQL query as MulitSelect or Select can not have nested values.

(/) *Expected Result for CascadingSelect*
We execute requests in batches, effectively reducing the numbers we query the database.

*The root of the problem*
Upon update operations, Multi Select loads all the data to validate the update. It browses all the fields that are defined for the issue and is checking whether we attempting to set any illegal value to a field.

The code to load Multi Select List and Cascading Select List is shared. Actually sharing the code makes loading of values sub-optimal for a Multi Select List.

(!) In *Multi Select List* - for each of the values, we verify whether we have any nested options, it's actually impossible to have ones for a *Multi Select List* (but is possible for *Cascading Select List*).

(!) It means that if we have a number *N* of *Mulit Select Lists* on a page with a number of Values *V* we will end up
*N\*V* queries to the database to warm up the cache.

(on) Ideas on how to fix it:
* Make a single query to DB/Cache to get the batch result for the children count, to evict values with no children. This should statistically make it faster.
* Pass some context in the CustomFieldOptionJsonBean so it will not attempt to query children to Multi Select List (as it can not have nested values, i.e. no children size is always 0).
* Eliminate code sharing between *Multi Select List* and *Cascading Select List*, for *Multi Select List* to load it's values in efficient way.
fields.summary: Multi Select Custom Field loads options in a suboptimal way

h3. Problem Definition
The references to GlobalId in [issuesWithRemoteLinksByGlobalId() documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+Searching+Functions#AdvancedSearchingFunctions-issuesWithRemoteLinksByGlobalId()] can be confusing or atleast obscure, in that it doesn't explain where the GlobalIds come from or how to retrieve them. Also, it's not clear if GlobalIds are only auto-generated or if they can be set explicitly e.g. for remote links added via REST API; or if they can be retrieved in an easy way other than from the database.

h3. Suggested Solution
Explain more or include a link to further definition on remote link GlobalID, and how a user could retrieve it for use in the issuesWithRemoteLinksByGlobalId() function.
fields.summary: Explain the concept and realistic usage examples of remote links GlobalId

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44569].
  {panel}

As per the documentation in https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Issues+and+Comments+from+Email , when a mail handler process an email, it first try to locate an issue key using the summary or the in-reply-to header and happen the email that issue, otherwise creating an issue on the configured project for the mail handler.

This can cause conflict in a setup where email addresses, mail handler and project are 1 to 1.
A mail handler could add a comment to another issue which has a similar key in the subject.

It would be convenient to have an option to have a mail handler be exclusive to a project, on creation AND commenting.

The logic would be:
Search in summary or in-reply-to header for an issue key.
If key exist AND issue is the mail handler project : Add comment
Otherwise Create issue in the mail handler project

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When creating an issue with the assignee field set to *Automatic* the expected behavior is like described at [Defining a Component|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Defining+a+Component]:
{quote}
Note that you can set a Default Assignee for a component. This will override the project's default assignee, for issues in that component.
{quote}

The above behavior is not respected when the component field is set from a post function, even when this post function is the first on the create issue transition.

If this is an expected behavior it should be documented, if not should be fixed.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a *Single Choice Select List* (e.g. CustomComponent) with the following option:
#* A
# Create two users:
#* componentlead
#* projectlead
# Create a project with the following component:
||name || lead || default assignee ||
| A | componentlead | Component Lead |
# Add the user 'projectlead' as the *Project Lead* of this project.
# Add a *Copy Value from Other Field* post-function from the *JIRA Suite Utilities Plugin* to the *Create Issue* transition for this project. 
#* Source: CustomComponent
#* Target: Component/s
# Create an issue and set "CustomComponent" to "A".

h3. Expected Results
JIRA issue is created with:
* {{CustomComponent}} = 'A';
* {{Component/s}} = 'A';
* Assignee = 'componentlead'

h3. Actual Results
JIRA issue is created with:
* {{CustomComponent}} = 'A';
* {{Component/s}} = 'A';
* Assignee = 'projectlead'

h3.Workaround
	Do not use post functions to set the Component/s field.
fields.summary: Component default assignee not respected when component is set by post function

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44546].
  {panel}

As of now, JIRA creates Issue Types in English first (irrespective of the instance language). After that, if you create projects, it adds new issue types in that language. However, the issue types in English are always there.

This can be confusing for the administrator. 

Steps to reproduce : 
# Set up a new instance and choose any language (other than English) in the beginning of the installation. I tested with German.
# Now proceed with the installation
# After the installation is complete, check the issue types on the instance
# Notice all issue types are created in English
# Now create a project
# Notice that now new issue types are created in the instance language.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like JIRA to create default issue types in the instance language

Thanks!

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44539].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Every so often, customers migrate from JIRA Cloud to JIRA Server, and support Engineers sometimes need to restore customer data on particular JIRA builds, when they do this they may need to compare build numbers of different JIRA versions.

Currently this is done by referencing this KB: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+Build+and+Version+Numbers+Reference

The KB is updated manually and as a result will fall out of sync with the latest version, this should be done as part of the release process.

h3. Suggested Solution
Instead of using a manually updated KB this information should be in developer.atlassian.com somewhere - look at how Confluence handles this https://developer.atlassian.com/confdev/development-resources/confluence-build-information
fields.summary: Add JIRA Build Information to developer.atlassian.com

h3. Summary

The Configure Fields menu does not show a complete scrollbar when rendering the custom tab containing all available fields

Please update the {{Please note}} section from the [Uninstalling JIRA from Linux|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Uninstalling+JIRA+from+Linux] documentation to include the information that the database is not deleted when running the uninstaller.

The suggestion for the change is like follows (change already applied to the online 6.4.x document version):

{quote}
Please note:

    * All files within the JIRA Installation Directory will be deleted (with the exception of the Tomcat log folder located in the JIRA Installation Directory).
    * The uninstaller will NOT delete:
       ** The JIRA database
       ** The JIRA Home Directory
       ** Log files that were generated while JIRA was running
    * The uninstaller can be made to operate in unattended mode by specifying the -q option — i.e. uninstall -q
{quote}

Thanks!
fields.summary: Update the 'Uninstalling JIRA from Linux' documentation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44486].
  {panel}

Based on the following documentation; [Advanced Searching Functions - startOfWeek()|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+Searching+Functions#AdvancedSearchingFunctions-startOfWeek()], the result of startOfWeek() function is depends upon your locale. 

Some customers wants to maintain their locale, but want to change the day the week starts in JIRA. As a workaround, startOfWeek("inc") function accept increment where inc is an optional increment of (+/-)nn(y|M|w|d|h|m). For example, if user wants to make:
* Sunday to be the start of week: startOfWeek("-1d")
* Saturday to be the start of week: startOfWeek()
* Monday to be the start of week: startOfWeek("+1d")
fields.summary: Update documentation on Advanced Searching Functions - startOfWeek()

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When JIRA transitions an issue, the WorkflowUIDispatcher,jspa is running an update query to the jiraissue table in the database twice.

This has the effect of increasing the time the transition takes. JIRA does not need to update the same table twice with the same data.

It appears that JIRA is attempting to record the issue and then also store the issue again, which is resulting in two update queries being sent to the database.

h3. Environment
N/A

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable SQL Logging and Dumps
# Transition an issue
# Observe that identical update queries are being executed from the {{/secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa}} within the {{atlassian-jira-sql.log}}

h3. Expected Results
JIRA should avoid updating a table twice with the same data to be more performant.

h3. Actual Results
{code}
2015-07-24 16:10:58,067 http-bio-18000-exec-10 admin 970x932x1 smqexw /secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa 0ms "UPDATE public.jiraissue SET pkey='null', issuenum='5', PROJECT='10001', REPORTER='admin', ASSIGNEE='null', CREATOR='admin', issuetype='10001', SUMMARY='As a team, I'd like to commit to a set of stories to be completed in a sprint (or iteration) >> Click "Create Sprint" then drag the footer down to select issues for a sprint (you can't start a sprint at the moment because one is already active)', DESCRIPTION='*Starting a Sprint*

During the Planning Meeting the team will examine the stories at the top of the backlog and determine which they can commit to completing during the coming sprint. Based on this information the Product Owner might break down stories into smaller stories, adjust story priorities or otherwise work with the team to define the ideal sprint outcome. When the sprint is started the stories are moved into the sprint backlog.', ENVIRONMENT='null', PRIORITY='3', RESOLUTION='null', issuestatus='10001', CREATED='2015-06-15 16:17:19.089', UPDATED='2015-07-24 16:10:58.066', DUEDATE='null', RESOLUTIONDATE='null', VOTES='0', WATCHES='0', TIMEORIGINALESTIMATE='null', TIMEESTIMATE='null', TIMESPENT='null', WORKFLOW_ID='10005', SECURITY='null', FIXFOR='null', COMPONENT='null' WHERE ID='10005'"
2015-07-24 16:10:58,068 http-bio-18000-exec-10 admin 970x932x1 smqexw /secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa call stack

...
...

2015-07-24 16:10:58,095 http-bio-18000-exec-10 admin 970x932x1 smqexw /secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa 1ms "UPDATE public.jiraissue SET pkey='null', issuenum='5', PROJECT='10001', REPORTER='admin', ASSIGNEE='null', CREATOR='admin', issuetype='10001', SUMMARY='As a team, I'd like to commit to a set of stories to be completed in a sprint (or iteration) >> Click "Create Sprint" then drag the footer down to select issues for a sprint (you can't start a sprint at the moment because one is already active)', DESCRIPTION='*Starting a Sprint*

During the Planning Meeting the team will examine the stories at the top of the backlog and determine which they can commit to completing during the coming sprint. Based on this information the Product Owner might break down stories into smaller stories, adjust story priorities or otherwise work with the team to define the ideal sprint outcome. When the sprint is started the stories are moved into the sprint backlog.', ENVIRONMENT='null', PRIORITY='3', RESOLUTION='null', issuestatus='10001', CREATED='2015-06-15 16:17:19.089', UPDATED='2015-07-24 16:10:58.066', DUEDATE='null', RESOLUTIONDATE='null', VOTES='0', WATCHES='0', TIMEORIGINALESTIMATE='null', TIMEESTIMATE='null', TIMESPENT='null', WORKFLOW_ID='10005', SECURITY='null', FIXFOR='null', COMPONENT='null' WHERE ID='10005'"
2015-07-24 16:10:58,095 http-bio-18000-exec-10 admin 970x932x1 smqexw /secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa call stack
{code}

h3. Notes
This behaviour is currently expected and required for JIRA to handle various issue update circumstances with Post Functions on workflows. While the process of updating the issue twice is less than ideal a working database should not have too many issues swiftly locating the correct entry to update (at least the second time round). The example here shows these updates taking 1ms, 0ms respectively. 

Databases in which a performance problem is indicated based on these updates, are typically affected by other factors, such as a third party triggers added to the affected tables (which is not recommended or supported), or slow database disk speeds. These should be addressed firstly as those problems have more of a global impact on the performance of a JIRA environment than this reported issue.
fields.summary: Slow workflow transitions due to duplicate updates to JIRA database

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you create a 2 Dimensional gadget from a saved filter, which returns no issues it shows ‘No Matching Issues Found', without showing the filter name. This makes it difficult to differentiate between gadgets.  The Filter name is displayed only if the filter returns more than 0 records.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a saved filter which will return no issues 
# Create a 2-Dimensional gadget on the dashboard from the filter

h3. Expected Results

The filter name should be shown at the bottom of the gadget.

h3. Actual Results
It just shows ‘No Matching Issues Found'
fields.summary: Cannot view Filter name in 2-dimensional filter in case of 0 result

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44474].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
If an issue is part of an Epic and also has sub-tasks, then the sub-task does not contain the Epic Link field. This makes it very difficult to run reporting on all issues with an Epic.


h3. Suggested Workaround
Use Script Runner (or any other plugin) to copy the field "Epic Link" to the some field on Sub-tasks. This would help to query the sub-tasks on the issue navigator.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like the "Epic Link" field to be available to the sub-tasks.
